Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Perioperative Gabapentin for Postoperative Pain and Opioid Cessation

Participants.evidence: A total of 1805 patients aged 18 to 75 years scheduled for surgeries such as thoracotomy, total hip replacement, and mastectomy were screened.

Intervention.evidence: Gabapentin (1200 mg preoperatively and 600 mg three times daily postoperatively) was compared to an active placebo (lorazepam, 0.5 mg preoperatively followed by inactive placebo postoperatively for 72 hours).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was time to pain resolution, defined as five consecutive reports of zero pain at the surgical site.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Patients, clinicians, and outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants were enrolled from May 25, 2010, to July 25, 2014, and followed for 2 years.

Number_Analysed.evidence: 422 were randomised: 202 to placebo and 208 to gabapentin. Intention-to-treat analysis showed no effect on pain cessation

Result_Outcome.evidence: Intention-to-treat analysis showed no effect on pain cessation (HR, 1.04; 95% CI, 0.82-1.33; P = .73) but a 24% increase in opioid cessation rate (HR, 1.24; 95% CI, 1.00-1.54; P = .05).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were similar between groups, with sedation or dizziness leading to medication discontinuation in 20.8% of placebo and 25.0% of gabapentin patients.
